I was reading in The Economist an interesting article about ants and it says : that the success of ants as a species lies in their sophisticated, strictly hierarchical social organisations. Ant colonies are founded on two main “castes” of ant: queens, whose sole function is reproduction, and their industrious, sterile, worker daughters. (The only use for males is to inseminate the queen; afterwards they are either driven out of the nest or killed.)
 
 This is similar to the bees where the drones fly to to mate with the queen bee, only one gets lucky but dies soon afterwards (with a smile on his face?)
 and the other drones soon follow his fate. Spiders and praying mantis also seem to consider males as someone to dispense with after intercourse.
 
 How come this dispensing with the male of the species did not become universal?

 To sum up;
 
 a) It may make evolutionary sense for MEN (or at least, a good portion of MEN) to pursue this strategy, since they can potentially father such an enormous number of children in this manner, that the probabilities favour them, despite the reduced chance of any particular child surviving to reproductive age.
 
 b) This is generally a terrible strategy for women, since they can only be pregnant once at a time. Whether they're screwing 100 men or 1, they still end up with 1 baby. Having a loyal partner will increase the chances of both mother and child surviving longer, and thus their evolutionary chances.
 
 c) The issue is more complex than this, as you will find if you bother to read further, and in any population there will be a shifting equilibrium of strategies.

 Not necessarily a bad strategy for women:
 
 
What it boils down to is that concealed ovulation has repeatedly changed and actually reversed its function during primate evolutionary history. That is, both the father-at-home and the many-fathers explanations are valid, but they operated at different times in our evolutionary history. Concealed ovulation arose at a time when our ancestors were still promiscuous or living in harems. At such times, it let the ancestral woman distribute her sexual favors to many males, none of whom could swear that he was the father of her baby but each of whom knew that he might be. As a result, none of those potentially murderous males wanted to harm the baby, and some may actually have protected or helped feed it. Once the woman had evolved concealed ovulation for that purpose, she then used it to pick a good man, to entice or force him to stay at home with her, and to get him to provide lots of help for her baby.

 
 Sex and the Female Agenda | Sex & Reproduction | DISCOVER Magazine

Further tests on the DNA revealed surprisingly few evolutionary changes, which suggests that the Neanderthals may only ever have existed in relatively small numbers, with less than 10,000 alive at any one time.
 
 "This has implications for our picture of Neanderthals and perhaps the reasons for their extinction. If the population was teetering on the brink for hundreds of thousands of years, it maybe changes our impression of what it would have taken to make them go extinct rather than if there were millions of them," said Adrian Briggs, a molecular biologist who co-authored a report on the work in the journal Cell.

There is much debate on this issue about the Neanderthals. One opinion is that they couldn't reproduce fast enough, and one thing which put pressure on this is their shorter lifespans. I find it difficult to find any one simple explanation online.
 
 
Neandertals and modern humans may have shared similarly prolonged childhoods. But the fossil record from the late Stone Age (around 40,000 years ago)-when both species where living in Europe and western Asia-suggests that Neandertal adults were dying much younger. 
 
 Short life spans, Dean says, would have put populations under serious pressure. 
 
 "Neandertals presumably went extinct because they couldn't reproduce fast enough to survive," he said.

 
 Neanderthals Grew Fast, but Sexual Maturity Came Late

 As for your comments about a so-called debate over neanderthals. It's interesting that the most linked to sites talking about the decline of neanderthals made no mention of your reproduction theory at all, but more about physiological differences between neanderthal and man and how climate change made neanderthal unable to adapt, while early man was.

Young Neanderthals' rapid growth required lots of energy, experts say. 
 "Neanderthals must have had a rich diet in protein and fat for children to fuel rapid growth in [their] brains," said Holly Smith of the Museum of Anthropology at the University of Michigan, who was not involved in the research.
 
 Mothers also likely had to consume vast quantities of calories to produce enough breast milk.
 
 This energy-intensive child rearing may have caused "somewhat longer interbirth intervals, or somewhat older mothers," study co-author Zollikofer said.

 
 Afarensis: Neanderthals, Brain Size, and Maturation: Does Breastfeeding or Fish Eating Have an Impact?

Afarensis: Neanderthals, Brain Size, and Maturation: Does Breastfeeding or Fish Eating Have an Impact?

 
 Based upon the reading I've done on the subject, and your half-hearted attempts to argue your position, I've made my conclusion that your position is ridiculous. I'll withhold further comments about why you would make such a ridiculous argument for now.

The researchers’ analysis of the Neanderthal toddlers’ growth rate lead them to hypothesize that Neanderthal babies grew more quickly in their early years than Homo sapiens, which could have placed a burden on their mothers. “Neanderthals must have had a rich diet in protein and fat for children to fuel rapid growth in [their] brains,” said [anthropologist] Holly Smith. Mothers also likely had to consume vast quantities of calories to produce enough breast milk. This energy-intensive child rearing may have caused “somewhat longer interbirth intervals, or somewhat older mothers,” study co-author [Christoph] Zollikofer said [National Geographic News]. But while Zollikofer suggests that this disadvantage may account for the Neanderthals’ eventual disappearance from the world, other researchers say that he is drawing hasty conclusions.
 
 Neanderthal Mothers Had It Tougher Than Modern Moms | 80beats | Discover Magazine
 
 Here is the original article, in which Chris Zollikofer talks about brain size and efficiency and how it relates to reproduction rates(look especially at page 4, first paragraph from the top):
 
 Neanderthal brain size at birth provides insights into the evolution of human life history ? PNAS

That large, faster-growing brain came with a price tag. Neanderthal mothers probably needed to dedicate more resources-food and maternal care-to their infants than modern humans do. From this study [subscription required], Zollikofer concludes that Neanderthal mothers may have had their first child, on average, when they were a year or two older than modern humans and that their time between pregnancies was probably longer. 
 
 #8: Cavemen: They're Just Like Us | Neanderthals | DISCOVER Magazine

Well Jake, you're arguing 3 things here
 
 1) Neanderthals reproduce more slowly. You haven't provided any good evidence for this.
 
 2) Neanderthals suffer from reproducing more slowly, and in fact this is why they died out.

 Either 2) or 3) may be true, but both can't be true at the same time. You're twisting yourself in knots trying to justify bs you made up in the first place for the sole purpose of defending gayness from someone who is anti-gay.

Well, no Neanderthals don't benefit in the long run, because they were inefficient. Humans evolved more efficient brains, which didn't grow at the same terrifically fast rate early in life. That didn't require more resources, and more breastfeeding, which has an effect on fertility. 
 
 Also, the Neaderthals died off more quickly, and failed to replace themselves. They did have to wait a longer interval between reproducing than humans.
 
 Yes, it's true you can say they benefited from not reproducing as quickly, but they still didn't reproduce enough, and not efficiently enough, to keep extinction at bay. I think one can argue both points, in relation to their inferior reproduction outcomes.
